Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the significance of Latino voters in deciding the popular vote margin, as it implies that this has never happened before in history.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to fully substantiate the assertion that this is the first time in history that the Latino vote margin has been larger than the national popular vote margin.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge that a similar scenario occurred in 2000 when Al Gore won the popular vote by a smaller margin than the net gain he received from Latino voters, suggesting that there may be alternative explanations for the claim.
